data.title: The Amphibians and Reptiles of Scotland
data.meta_description: New book available for free download!
data.text:
Sand Wasps benefit from lizard conservation

ARC reserves are havens for many different organisms, not only reptiles and amphibians. Warm dry heathlands are home to a large proportion of ~ 500 species of nest-building wasps and bees.

ARC-BHS Joint Scientific Meeting 2024

The ARC-BHS Joint Scientific Meeting is back for 2024 on Saturday 30th November, with a range of fascinating talks about amphibian and reptile biology and conservation.

Pembrey Country Park - Steam Rally and Country Fayre

Find ARC's Adder Action Officer at the Pembrey Country Park Steam Rally & Country Fayre!

Planet Purbeck Festival 2024

ARC will be attending the Nature and Wellbeing Fair as part of the Planet Purbeck Festival 2024!

Sand Wasps benefit from lizard conservation

ARC reserves are havens for many different organisms, not only reptiles and amphibians. Warm dry heathlands are home to a large proportion of ~ 500 species of nest-building wasps and bees.

A Springwatch Recap from Howard Inns

ARC Trustee, Howard Inns gives his roundup of behind-the-scenes of this year's BBC Springwatch.

SSAAR: a splendid summer so far

ARC‚Äôs SSAAR Education Officer, Janet Ullman updates us on a busy summer so far; a prize winning Champhibian School student, a new slow-worm survey, bringing Gaelic into our work and more.

Recorder‚Äôs day on four of ARC‚Äôs north Wales nature reserves

Cofnod and local ecological experts brought their expertise to four of ARC‚Äôs nature reserves in northeast Wales this summer to help increase the recorded biodiversity of sites in a wonderful knowledge exchange.

Snakeskins, citizen science and saving species‚Ä¶

ARC has maintains a ‚Äúbank‚Äù of reptile sloughs made available to researchers or universities investigating aspects of reptile biology, conservation or taxonomy. Find out more about what we do with them!

Unveiling Slow-Worms of Highland

A guest blog from Cally Ullman-Smith, detailing a new monitoring project: the Scottish Slow-worm Project.

Thousands march to parliament to demand politicians Restore Nature Now

Amphibian and Reptile Conservation joined more than 60,000 people and over 350 charities, businesses and action groups to march through central London. They had one simple but powerful message to the UK‚Äôs political parties ‚Äì that they must Restore Nature Now.

Nursery School Pupils Win Prize for Naming New Educational Mascot

Highlands, 17th June 2024. National wildlife charity, Amphibian and Reptile Conservation (ARC) is thrilled to announce the newest character joining their adopt-a-pond schools programmes: Losgy an Losgann!

Facts and advice on adder bites

Facts about adder bites and answers to frequently asked questions about prevention and treatment. This text is based on ARC‚Äôs research and experience, published evidence, and authoritative sources.
